metadata.title: Robust superhydrophilic polylactide (PLA) membrane with TiO2 nano-particles inlayed surface for oil/water separation

sections.text:

polymeric membrane especially with superwetting behaviour. A robust superhydrophilic surface was fabricated by nano-TiO2 inlayed on hierarchical polylactide (PLA) ultrafiltration membrane via a spin coating process. Distinctly different from most previously reported nano-particles involved polymeric membranes, both micro-/nano- architecture of PLA membrane and size matched nano particles assembly constructed the robust superhydrophilic interface mimicking coral tentacles predatory behavior. The rigid surface based on flexible polymeric membrane with hierarchical architecture showed robust superhydrophilicity and underwater superoleophobicity even after long-time water washing treatment, which was also verified by the morphology, contact angle, XPS and adhesive force in contrast to smooth membrane. The as-prepared PLA membrane showed excellent separation performance in varieties of oil/water mixtures separation with robustly high permeate flux (above 950 L/m2·h under 0.1 MPa) and oil rejection (above 99%) even after 10 cycles operation. Besides, the superhydrophilic PLA membrane exhibited outstanding anti-protein fouling property. The PLA membranes showed relatively high BSA and ink rejection, respectively, as well as the water flux recovery and continuous separation stability due to rigid interface strengthening effect. The unique interface combination strategy between functional nanoparticles and polymeric membrane provided a window of opportunity for constructing robust polymeric membrane for advanced applications e.g. oil/water separation, ion exchange and membrane catalytic reactor etc.
Keywords: robust superhydrophilic, PLA membrane, rigid surface, hierarchical texture.

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text:
In recent years, materials with special wettability have attracted extensive interest for their great application in oil/water separation to resolve the globally increasing oil pollution. 1-5 Nevertheless, contaminants in water from oil spill accidents not only include oily substances, but also involve water-miscible organic molecules, which need to be removed urgently in an effective way. 6 Thus, various materials are designed to purify water in an economical and energy efficient method to meet the growingly stringent water standards. Considering that, advanced membranes with separation efficiency and durability should be further developed to achieve the deep purification of water. 7
In order to purify oil contaminated water, microfiltration and ultrafiltration membranes, such as poly(vinylidene fluoride) (PVDF), 8-11 polyethersulfone (PES), 12 polypropylene (PP), 13 polysulfone (PSF), 14 have been greatly investigated towards super-wettability modification. However, those above membranes originated from petroleum are high cost, non-sustainable, non-degradable and environmental challenging in the future, which could cause white pollution and increase energy crisis after their large utilization and disposal. Thus, it is desirable to develop environmental benign and sustainable microporous membranes from bio-based and biodegradable materials, such as poly(lactic acid) (PLA). 15-19 The hydrophobic PLA membrane needs to be harnessed with hydrophilicity for oil resistance, antifouling and removal efficiency in case of oil contained water mixture separation. 20-22 Recently, our group has reported that the hydrophilicity and antifouling of PLA membranes could be improved by the blending and surface crosslinking of hydrophilic polymers. 23-26 However, the oil-water separation performance cannot be achieved easily by the hydrophilic PLA membrane. Superhydrophilicity and underwater superoleophobicity with textured surface is required for the oil-water separation. 7
Prof. Jin’ group fabricated a super-hydrophobic/super-oleophilic PVDF membrane via ammonia and salt induced phase-inversion process. 8 Different from common-phase inversion, the addition of ammonia is prone to induce PVDF cluster and form spherical particles, which enhanced the PVDF surface roughness and superwettability. Similarly, they prepared superhydrophilic PVDF membranes grafted with ionized poly(acrylic acid) for efficient separation of oil-water mixtures. 9, 10 Thanks to its strong hydration capability and surface hierarchical structure, the PVDF membrane exhibited underwater ultralow-oil-adhesive to viscous oils. Our group reported an effective methodology to prepare the superwetting PVDF membrane with the micro/nanoscale hierarchical structure via the phase inversion and non-woven fabric (NWF) peeling off. 11 The obtained PVDF membrane displayed the switchable ability between superhydrophobicity under oil and superoleophobicity under water. It was generally thought that the micro-/nano-scale structure played a crucial role for the realization of superwettability. However, the polymeric based micro-/nano-scale structure has been a challenge in long term durability due to the creep deformation of flexible polymers. 27, 28 Besides, the oil adhesion and protein absorption is also occurring on hierarchical surface with high surface area as irreversible fouling.
Inspired by the outstanding oil resistance and anti-biofouling of fish scales and clamshell in aqueous media, 29, 30 many researchers have used minerals (such as CaCO3, SiO2, graphene oxides and TiO2) with inherent structural stability and hydrophilicity to decorate the membrane surface for oil-water separation. For example, Yang et. al 13 used the dopamine to induce poly-condensation of silicic acid and fabricated a silica-decorated polypropylene (PP) membrane. Results showed that the SiO2-mineral coating provided the PP membrane with expected superhydrophilicity in air and underwater superhydrophobicity. With the function of SiO2-mineral coating, the PP membrane can be effectively applied in varieties of oil/water separation. In pursuit of outstanding oil-water separation, similar method was also developed by membranes via the TiO2, 31 graphene, 32, 33 and nanotube coating. 34 The stabilized surface chemical characteristic and morphology of mineral coatings could endow different polymeric membranes with robust oil/water separation property. However, the covered inorganic coating on smooth polymeric membrane was mainly formed by electrostatic inter-actions or hydrogen bonding. 35-38 Therefore, the low stability owing to the weak interfacial bonding between membrane and coating has to be taken fully into account. To resolve these problems, an intermediate layer is required to robustly connect the membrane surfaces with the inorganic coating. Very recently, Lu et al 27 used a dual adhesive tape as intermediate layer to immobilize the superwettable nano-TiO2 particles on various substrates for fabricating the robustly superwettable surface. It showed that the super-wettability of those modified surfaces were durable to finger-wipe, knife-scratch, and multiple abrasion cycles with sandpaper friction damage, indicating the super-stability of nano-TiO2 coating fixed by the intermediate adhesive layer. Unfortunately, this kind of intermediate adhesive layer was dense and un-transmitted, which could shield the surface porous structure while adhered on the membrane. Ultimately, the separation of oil-water mixture cannot be realized in the aqueous environments for polymer membranes.
Therefore, a facile and more environmental benign method is aimed to be developed to construct robust superhydrophilic membrane without any “glue” or “tape” involved. The PLA membrane with hierarchical surface was first prepared via phase separation and template peeling. The diverse micro-/nano- structure was capable of capturing, restraining and confining TiO2 nano-particles inside due to the higher actual surface area and higher adsorptive capability and therefore form the robust coating on PLA membrane. The inlay and assembly of nano-TiO2 is mimicking the coral tentacles predatory behaviour. The surface chemistry, roughness, superwettability and the morphology of the robust PLA membrane surface was characterized in detailed. Besides, the robustness of nano-TiO2 coating was also evaluated for long-term water flushing. Finally, the oil-water separation efficiency, permeability, rejection, and protein fouling resistance were comprehensively investigated.

Toluene (AR), paraffin oil (CP) and soybean oil (CP) were all purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. (China). Lubricating oil (Teresstic T32) was bought from Mobil (America). The black ink was bought from Shanghai Hero Co., Ltd (China) to assess the rejection. The non-woven fabric (PET, 80 g/m2) was bought from Shanghai JiuJun Co., Ltd (China).
Fabrication of PLA membrane with hierarchical surface: The composite PLA membrane with non-woven fabric as the support was firstly prepared via non-solvent induced phase separation (NIPS) method. 18 Preset 18 g PLA and 5 g β-CD were dissolved in 82 g NMP at 80 oC for 18 h under 300 rpm mechnical stirring. Afterwards, the solution was deaerated under reduced pressure and then heated to 80 oC to obtain uniform PLA casting solution, which was subsequently spreaded onto the PET non-woven fabric (NWF) (80 g/m2) by a casting knife with the thickness of 200 μm. The liquid film coated on NWF was immediately immersed into water coagulation bath for 5 min. After total solidification, the membrane was transferred to the fresh water for 24 h, and then dried in the air to obtain the NWF sopported PLA membrane. Lastly, the PLA membrane with hierarchical surface was peeled off from the NWF, as schemed in Figure 1 and Moive S1.
Figure 1. Schematic illustration for the fabrication of robust superhydrophilic PLA membrane. Hydrophilic nano-TiO2 modified by the interfacial crosslinking P(VP-VTES) was inlayed on the hierarchical surface of PLA membrane peeled from NFW. The interface combination mimicks the coral tentacles predatory behavior.
Fabrication of robust PLA membrane with TiO2 coating: Firstly, the hydrophilic P(VP-VTES) copolymer was synthesized as following: 3.75 g NVP, 2.75 VTES and 0.16 g AIBN was sequentially added into the 100 g alcohol, in which AIBN was used as the initiator.24-26 The free radical polymerization was carried out at 65 °C with continuous stirring under a nitrogen for 24 h to obtain the P(VP-VTES)/alcohol solution. After that, 1.5 g nano-TiO2 was added to make a paint-like suspension after 2 h ultrasonic treatment. TiO2 nano particles were decorated by the hydrophilic copolymer via the hydrolysis, condensation and crosslinking. Subsequently, these hydrophilic TiO2
nanoparticles were immobilized on the hierachical surface of PLA membrane via a spin-coating method to fabricate the robust superhydrophilic surface, as shemed in Figure 1. Lastly, the TiO2 coated PLA membrane marked as TiO2-PLA-1 was dried in air for at least 36 h. As a contrast, TiO2 nanoparticles were also deposited on the smooth top surface of PLA membrane (PLA-2) via the spincoating and marked as TiO2-PLA-2. Moreover, the smooth bottom surface of the PLA membrane (PLA-3) directly obtained from glass plate in place of NWF was also utilized to load the TiO2 nanoparticles and marked as TiO2-PLA-3.
Characterization: Scanning electron microscopy (SEM, Hitachi, S4800, Japan) and Scanning Electron Microscope (SEM, FEI, Quanta 250, America) were used to detect the surface morphologies and element distribution of PLA membrane, respectively. Laser scanning confocal microscope (LSCM, Zeiss LSM 700) was utilized to observe the 3D roughness of PLA membranes. The surface chemical composition variation was detected by X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS, Axis Utra Dld, Japan). The water contact angles in air and oil contact angles under water were measured through a CA system (OCA20, Dataphysics, Germany). Laser scanning confocal microscope (LSCM, Leica TCS SP5, German) were taken to observe the surface protein adsorption. The adhesion forces of oil under water on the PLA membrane samples were measured using a high-sensitive microelectromechanical balance system (Data-Physics DCAT11, Germany). The reciprocating oscillator (HY-4A, XinBao Instrument Factory, China) was used to test the robustness of mineral coating on membranes under water environment.
In order to demonstrate the oil-water separation availability of PLA membranes, four types of oils including toluene, paraffin oil, soybean oil and lubricating oil mixed with water in 1: 1 (v/v) were prepared. A dead-end filtration apparatus was applied for testing the permeability of oil-water separation, and the trans-membrane pressure was adjusted at 0.1 MPa by a circulating water vacuum pump (SHZ-IIID, YuHua Instrument Co., Ltd, China). To further assess the rejection and recovery of TiO2 coated PLA membrane, the ink solution (1mL pristine ink in 1 L pure water) was filtered in our cross-flow device. During this process, the permeated liquid was consecutively collected and weighted every 5 min at 0.1 MPa for 30 min, and then the separation efficiency of this ink solution was mearsured by a DLS measurement (Zetasizer Nano ZS , Malvern, UK). After that, the ink contaminated PLA membrane sample was taken out and rinsed by deionized water for 15 min to remove the ink pollutant. Accomplished by that, the ink solution was changed into pure water to observe the flux recovery of PLA membrane. After 30 min, the pure water was again changed into ink solution to study the rejection stability of the PLA membrane samples. sections.heading: Results and discussion
sections.text:
Morphology, surface chemistry and superwettability of PLA membrane
For the advanced oil/water separation performance, both the surface micro-/nano- structure and chemical composition of membranes are supposed to play a crucial role.7 Figure 2 shows the SEM images of the PLA membrane hierarchical surfaces and cross-sections. The hierarchical PLA membrane surface is rather crumpled and raspy with micro-scale grooves [Figure 2 (a)], micropores [Figure 2 (a1)] and stretched nanofibrils [Figure 2 (b, b1)]. The size matched TiO2 nanoparticles were captured by the streched nanofibrils behaving like the coral tentacles and confined by the micropores to form the robust TiO2@P(VP-VTES) coating on the flexilbe PLA membrane, which can be identified in Figure 2 c and 2 d1. The plentiful micro-/nanostructure offered a high surface area to adsorp nanoparticles. Especially from the higher magnification image in Figure 2 (c1, d), it
is clearly found that the TiO2@P(VP-VTES) nanoparticles was depositing and covering the tentacles on the membrane surface.
Figure 2. SEM images of: (a, a1, b, b1) the surface and cross section of the pristine PLA membrane peeled from NWF, (c, c1, d, d1) the surface and cross section of TiO2-PLA-1membrane.
Figure 3. (a) SEM image of TiO2-PLA-1membrane surface; (b) EDX mapping of various elements distribution on TiO2-PLA-1membrane surface; (c) XPS wide scan of the pristine PLA membrane surface e; (d) XPS wide scan of the TiO2-PLA-1membrane surface, the inset shows the elemental mass percentages

Meanwhile, a clear and uniform distribution of Si and N were also detected respectively, indicating the presence of hydrophilic copolymer P(VP-VTES) on TiO2 surface membrane via crosslinking.24, 25 The surface chemical components were further characterized by XPS. As exhibited in Figure 3c, only two peaks attributed to carbon (C 1s) and oxygen (O 1s) appeared on the pristine PLA membrane surface.26 In contrast, the TiO2 decorated PLA membrane distinctly exhibited new peaks of titanium (Ti 2p) at 462 eV, nitrogen (N 1s) at 398 eV and silicon (Si 2s/2p) at 98/150 eV in Figure 3 (d). Furthermore, as calculated from the XPS in Figure 3 (d), the percentage of Ti 2p, N 1s and Si 2s/2p is 14.8%, 5.5% and 6.2%, respectively, demonstrating the high loading of TiO2 nanoparticles and P(VP-VTES) modifier on the TiO2-PLA-1 membrane surface.
Figure 4. The 3D images of (a) the pristine PLA membrane and (b) the TiO2-PLA-1membrane; The water contact angle of (c) the pristine PLA membrane and (d) the TiO2-PLA-1membrane; The oil contact angle of (e) the pristine PLA membrane and (f) the TiO2-PLA1membrane underwater; Real-time recorded force-distance curves for (g) the pristine hierarchical PLA membrane surface and (h) TiO2PLA-1membrane surface during the dynamic adhesion measurements
Commonly, the surface superwettability can be achieved by designing chemical affinity and micro-/nano- hierarchical structures. 7 For the pristine PLA membrane in Figure 4 (c), the hierarchical surface exhibited highly hydrophobicity with the steady water contact angle of 107o in 60 s due to the high surface roughness (Rsa 9.8 μm in Figure 4 (a). With the inlay and assembly of nano-TiO2 into the grooves, micropores with the aid of nanofibrils tentacles, nano-TiO2@P(VPVTES) coated surface decreased the roughness to 5.6 μm accordingly. And the nano-TiO2@P(VP-VTES) decorated surface showed the excellent superhydrophicility with the water contact angle instantaneously dropping to zero in 6 s [Figure 4 (d)]. Besides, the red
droplet immediately spread out on the membrane surface and stained the membrane with red (Movie S2 in Supporting Information). But, the red droplet still stood on the hydrophobic PLA membrane.
Furthermore, the underwater superoleophobicity and oil repelling property were characterized by the 1,2-Dichloroethane for PLA membranes. 13 As shown in Figure 4e, the underwater oil contact angle (OCA) is 54o, and also an obvious deformation with large adhesion force of 22 μN is observed when lifting the oil droplet up on the membrane surface [Figure 4(g)], indiciating the pristine hierarchical PLA membrane showed certain affinity and adhesion to oil underwater. In contrast, the TiO2 coated PLA membrane displayed a high underwater oil contact angle (OCA) of 154±1o, and no obvious deformation of the oil droplet with the very low adhesion force of 4.7 μN was observed during the contacting test [Figure 4 (h)]. The obvious contrast showed that the TiO2 coated PLA membrane showed the outstanding superoleophobicity underwater. This is because that the water trapped in the hierarchical TiO2 coating formed a stable hydration layer to reduce the contacting opportunity between oil and PLA, which therefore provided a potential candidate for oil/water separation.

sections.heading: The robustness of superwettability for TiO2-inlayed PLA

Especially, the rapid shear flow on the membrane surface will accelerate the loss of nanoparticles from the membrane surface during the cross flow operation, which consequently cause the decline of superwettability. The micro-/nano- morphology of the membrane surface substantially influenced the fixing of nanoparticles. Speculated by that, three TiO2-coated PLA membranes with different surface morphology were prepared and vibrated in water bath from the cross direction for 24 h to investigate the robustness of the coating layer. As observed in Figure 5 (a, b), an apparent TiO2 coating, which anchored by the coral tentacles, was still preserved on the TiO2-PLA-1 membrane surface even after violent washing. As detected by XPS and roughness (Rsa 7.4 μm) in Figure 5 (c, d), the content of TiO2 nanoparticles and surface crosslinked P(VPVTES) still kept a high level to provide the superhydrophilicity. Therefore, as shown in Figure 5 (e) and Movie S3, when the red water droplet contacted the washed TiO2-PLA-1 membrane, it immediately spreaded out and diffused in three dimension along the membrane surface. The water contact angle is almost zero and the oil contact angle under water is 156±1o, indicating the underwater superoleophobicity.
Figure 6. The surface SEM images of (a) pristine PLA-2 membrane, (b) PLA-2 membrane coated with nano-TiO2, (c) the washed TiO2PLA-2 membrane, (d) pristine PLA-3 membrane, (e) PLA-3 membrane coated with nano-TiO2, and (f) the washed TiO2-PLA-3 membrane, insets are the enlarged views and water contact angles
Furthermore, as demonstrated by the dynamic adhesion test in Figure 5 (h), the washed TiO2 coating exhibited the ultra-low oil adhsion force (2.8 μN) under water. It was thought that the polymeric micro/nano- texture played a crucial role of anchoring the nanoparticles. And also the micropores of the membrane surface matched the size of nanoparticles TiO2. The nanoparticles were captured by the coral tentacles-like fibers and confined in the micropores, and then generated the uniform organic-inorganic hybrid layer through the perfect interface combination between flexible polymeric membrane and rigid nanoparticles. In contrast, the PLA membrane with the smooth surface (top surface of PLA-2, and bottom surface obtained from glass plate of PLA-3) was spin coated by nano-TiO2, respectively. The stabilty of such coating was checked respectively. From the magnification images in Figure 6 (b, e), the nano-TiO2 are both simply covered on the TiO2-PLA-2 and TiO2-PLA-3 membrane surfaces to form the sheet-like coating, and then endow the two PLA membranes with excellent hydrophilicity as the WCA decreased to zero. However, after violently washing the above PLA membranes for
only 1 h, the nano-TiO2 coatings almost diasppeared for TiO2-PLA-2 and TiO2-PLA-3 membranes, repectively, as exhibited in Figure 6 (c, f). As results, the WCAs on the washed TiO2-PLA-2 and TiO2-PLA3 membrane surfaces rebounced back to 54o and 46o, respectively, indicating the decay of the superhydrophilicity and the loss of coating.
Moreover, We evaluated the superhydrophilic robustness under chemical corrosion of strong acid (pH=0) and strong alkali (pH=13) (Figure S1, Movie S4) for the TiO2-PLA-1 membrane surfaces, respectively. The detailed experimental results were discussed in Supporting Information. It was clear that the superhydrophilicity could be well protected by the inlayed TiO2 interface on the rigid TiO2-PLA-1 membrane, which is promising for the separation of oil/water mixture in the harshly chemical environment. Overall, The hierarchical PLA membrane peeled from the nonwoven fabric have higher actual surface area than the smooth PLA membrane and may provide strong adsorptive capability for the size matched nano-TiO2 particles. The hierarchical morphology is composed of micropores and nanofibers. The diverse micro-/nano- texture is capable of restraining and confining nano-TiO2 inside and therefore form the robust coating on PLA membrane. The inlayed and assembly of TiO2 provided a protective armour to avoid the physical and chemical damage on PLA membrane micro-/nano- texture. The creep deformation of flexible polymeric chains was therefore protected by the rigid TiO2 armor.
Oil/water separation and anti-biofouling properties of the TiO2-
inlayed PLA membrane
As discussed above, the PLA membrane inlayed by TiO2 nanoparticles exhibited robust superhydrophilicity and underwater superoleophobicity, which is promising to treat oil-containing wastewater. 10, 11, 13, 22 As shown in Figure 7 (a) and Movie S5, when the robust TiO2-inlayed PLA membrane (TiO2-PLA-1) is immersed and lifted up repeatedly in a heavy lubricating oil, the membrane could be simply washed by water without oil adhesion and fouling. In contrast, the pristine PLA membrane was seriously contaminated by the adhered lubricating oil and is difficult to be cleaned by water (Movie S6). These results reveal the importance of stably hierarchical TiO2 coating on PLA membrane for anti-oil-adhesion and selfcleaning properties in an oil related aqueous environment.
Afterwards, we evaluated the separation performance of various oil/water mixtures via a dead-end filtration apparatus as shown in Figure 7 (b) and Movie S7. In order to reveal the separation efficiency, the total filtration time is 5 min in Figure 7 (b). It can be seen that the oil droplets were consistently prevented by the TiO2-inlayed PLA membranes. The results demonstrate that the TiO2-inlayed PLA membranes can effectively separate the oil drops with high water permeation flux and oil rejection. As exhibited in Figure 7 (c), the water permeation flux are 1018±16 L/m2·h, 1007±16 L/m2·h, 989±17 L/m2·h, and 963±21 L/m2·h, respectively, for toluene/water, paraffin oil/water, soybean oil/water and lubricating oil/water mixture, which is comparable to the pure water flux of the TiO2-inlayed PLA membrane, indicating the excellent oil fouling resistance. Meanwhile, TiO2-inlayed PLA membrane showed rejection higher than 99% for all oil/water mixture.

More importantly, we investigated the separation recyclability of the membrane for heavy oil/water mixture in multiple operations. As observed in Figure 7 (d), the membrane still showed high flux and high rejection even after ten cycles of separation, demonstrating the robustness of oil/water separation. In actually oily sewage, pollutants in water not only include oily substances, but also involve organic substance protein fouling. The protein adsorption fouling usually alters the initial physical and chemical properties of the membrane surfaces negatively, and consequently, significantly reduces the performance of the membranes. However, the robust hydration layer on a hydrophilic surface has a positive impact on blocking the ways of the surrounding protein molecules. The stable superhydrophilicity of the TiO2-inlayed PLA membrane is expected to have excellent antifouling performance. The FITC-labelled BSA was used as a model to assess the antifouling performance. 25, 39 As observed in Figure 7 (e, f and g), the TiO2-PLA-1 membrane shows almost no BSA adhesion and fluorescence effect after washing, while obviously stained yellow light with extremely dense fluorescence effect is found for the pristine PLA membrane due to the BSA adsorption. As obtained from the equation 2 and Figure 7 (h), the pristine PLA membrane displays a serious adsorption with the value of 17.8±2.1 mg/cm2. Interestingly, an obvious reduction of the adsorption of BSA was observed with the value of 2.2±0.6 mg/cm2 for TiO2-PLA-1 membrane. All BSA fouling results indicated that considerably enhanced anti-biofouling properties were endowed by the hydrophilic TiO2 inlayed surface.
Figure 7. Ultrafiltration performances of TiO2-PLA-1 membrane
The ultrafiltration performances of the TiO2-PLA-1 membrane for the dynamic BSA and ink separation in cross-flow device were evaluated as shown in Figure 8 (a). As observed in Figure 8 (b), the TiO2-PLA1 membrane could maintain its permeation stability for both pure water and BSA solution. Meanwhile, after two cycles of dynamic BSA filtration, the rejection of BSA still reached 75.6±2.1% for TiO2PLA-1 membrane in Figure 8 (c). In contrast, the pristine PLA membrane directly peeled from NWF exhibited the dramatically declined pure water flux in Figure 8 (b). As shown in Figure S2, the tensile strength and elongation at break of the pristine PLA membrane is about 2 MPa and 17%, respectively, which is higher than the 0.1 MPa operation pressure. After inlayed assembly of nanoparticles on the interface, the mechanical properties of the TiO2-PLA-1 membrane kept unchanged in comparison with the pristine PLA membrane. Thus, this phenomenon may be ascribed to the inherent flexibility of polymeric porous surface. The vulnerable surface will pressed and deformed by the water flow pressure, and therefore, the porous structure is getting dense and closes the free water channel for the membrane. Especially in the second cycle, the pure water flux is unexpectedly increased at 95 min, indicating the complete damage was generated and the barrier layer was destroyed in the pristine PLA membrane by the continuous water pressure. As a result, the BSA rejection decreased to 16.5±1.2% in Figure 8 (c). Besides, the ink solution comprising nano-carbon particles with the diameter from ~60

sections.heading: Conclusions
sections.text:
Unique bio-based PLA membrane with robust superhydrophilic
surface was fabricated via the nano-TiO2 particles inlayed in the
hierarchical texture. The size matched nanoparticles were captured by
the coral tentacles-like fibrils and then confined in the micropores to
form the rigid and robust TiO2 armour. The TiO2-inlayed PLA
membrane showed stable superhydrophilicity, underwater
superoleophobicity and ultra-low oil droplets adhesion force in
comparison with the smooth membrane. With this special
superwettability, the as-prepared PLA membranes successfully
realized the high efficient separation in varieties of oil/water mixtures.
The membrane showed permeation flux higher than 930 L/m2·h and
rejection higher than 99% under 0.1 MPa for four oil/water mixtures.
In addition, the membrane exhibited stable permeability for heavy
lubricating oil/water mixture separation over ten cycles. Besides, the
robust PLA membrane inlayed by TiO2 demonstrated stable water
flux, permeability recovery and high rejection to BSA and ink over
long time operation. All results verified that the firmly inlayed TiO2
nanoparticles by the hierarchical texture provided a robust protective
armor and enabled the flexible PLA membrane applicable for efficient
oil/water mixture separation.

metadata.abstractText: To overcome the surface instability of traditional polymeric membrane especially with superwetting behaviour. A robust superhydrophilic surface was fabricated by nano-TiO2 inlayed on hierarchical polylactide (PLA) ultrafiltration membrane via a spin coating process. Distinctly different from most previously reported nano-particles involved polymeric membranes, both micro-/nanoarchitecture of PLA membrane and size matched nano particles assembly constructed the robust superhydrophilic interface mimicking coral tentacles predatory behavior. The rigid surface based on flexible polymeric membrane with hierarchical architecture showed robust superhydrophilicity and underwater superoleophobicity even after long-time water washing treatment, which was also verified by the morphology, contact angle, XPS and adhesive force in contrast to smooth membrane. The as-prepared PLA membrane showed excellent separation performance in varieties of oil/water mixtures separation with robustly high permeate flux (above 950 L/m2·h under 0.1 MPa) and oil rejection (above 99%) even after 10 cycles operation. Besides, the superhydrophilic PLA membrane exhibited outstanding anti-protein fouling property. The PLA membranes showed relatively high BSA and ink rejection, respectively, as well as the water flux recovery and continuous separation stability due to rigid interface strengthening effect. The unique interface combination strategy between functional nanoparticles and polymeric membrane provided a window of opportunity for constructing robust polymeric membrane for advanced applications e.g. oil/water separation, ion exchange and membrane catalytic reactor etc.
